top_comment.text:
Is this anime any good? I saw that Anitay rated this Not Worth Your Time, 
so I would like your opinion, users of YouTube. ﻿
top_comment.author: Ryan Lam

comments.text:
+Ryan Lam It's quite amazing, it's a "goosebumps invoking" anime, I really 
liked it, the first season is top notch, where the second season is quite 
rushed, it felt really like the anime needed more episodes and the final 
ending is... quite disappointing, you know the show leaves you behind with 
fake smiling, but the second season has much better fighting and the 
soundtrack of the anime is miraculous.
comments.author: Epsilon

comments.text:
With the ending if the second season I have a love hate relationship with 
this show.
The second season gets really slow in the middle, but picks up at the end.

top_comment.author: ✿ Koeru

comments.text:
+HighLevelPlayer I highly doubt it since the grammar in that sentence is 
wrong as well and the mentioned meaning for "Rade" is so old that I had to 
check that word myself. "Rade" can also mean wheel (very old-fashioned) and 
there are a few German cities that have that name. Oh and apparently 
there's a flower with that name (actually called "Kornrade").
comments.author: Paperblossom

comments.text:
+Paperblossom

After thinking it over, do you think they could have meant "The Clearing, 
you do not know" or "Clearly, you do not know"?
comments.author: HighLevelPlayer

comments.text:
Thanks for making that clear, and congratulations to both you and Jo on 
this great cover.
comments.author: HighLevelPlayer

comments.text:
+HighLevelPlayer  I decided to change that line since it's the one German 
sentence that makes no sense whatsoever -  I honestly can't tell you what 
it's supposed to translate to in English. "Rade" is basically another way 
to say "clearing", and the rest of the sentence means "that you don't 
know". That's why I came up with "Dinge die du tust" instead, which means 
"Things that you do (out of your own free will)"
comments.author: Paperblossom

comments.text:
+Paperblossom

Could you tell me what's with the "Dinge, die du tust"? The pamphlet that 
comes with the CD says the lyric is "Rade, die du nicht weißt."
comments.author: HighLevelPlayer

top_comment.text:
Saw subs with this subs:
[English part] I say „cry“
I say „liar“
I say „rise in hell“
I stand gazing down at death
Don’t say „oh”
Life is
I think
[German part] Es ist gute Frage, was ist das?
Leben was ist das?
Sie kam siehst du das?
Leben sie tut weil Haus und der Mann will
Leben was ist das?
Sie kam siehst du das?
Leben sie tut also in seinen Augen.
Now on 20 times I listen to the original and I try to understand what 
option correct. Especially German part - I live in Germany and if not 
strongly to listen attentively, both options seem correct. Not really 
clearly, accent not German... T___T﻿

top_comment.author: RakuMugetsu

comments.text:
+Doitsu
Das hat nichts mit lyrischer Freiheit oder veraltetem Ausdruck zu tun - der 
Verfasser der Lyrics hatte einfach keine allzu guten Deutschkenntnisse. Das 
sollte aber jedem, der Hiroyuki Sawanos Lieder kennt, klar sein.
Ich weiß nicht, ob es in Japan an guten Deutsch-Japanisch-Übersetzern 
mangelt, aber man sieht häufig solche grammatikalischen Fehlgriffe.

Mich stört es eher weniger, denn ich finde die Musikkomposition wunderschön 
und fühle mich geehrt, meine Muttersprache in japanischen Liedern erwähnt 
zu finden. Aber dass die Texte inhaltlich korrekt sind - nein, tut mir 
leid, da kann ich dir beim besten Willen nicht zustimmen. :'DD
comments.author: LaNoir

comments.text:
+LaNoir
Verzeih mir wenn ich mich nicht richtig ausgedrückt habe.
Natürlich würde niemand das im Alltag so sagen. Heut zu tage sagt auch 
keiner mehr: "Du Tor!" oder "Welch Tor du doch bist!". Heute sagt man: "Du 
dummkopf".

Es ist außerdem auch ein Lied und in Liedern ist vieles anderst...
comments.author: Doitsu

comments.text:
+Doitsu
Ich denke nicht, dass ein Deutscher so einen Satz bauen würde.

Am I wrong?
comments.author: LaNoir

comments.text: +LaNoir  lol
comments.author: Edms Pack

comments.text:
+NightcoreZombies
The only pun I can see is that he tries to find words that sound the same 
but sometimes are hard to understand. So you have to understand it in a 
literary way.
I said - should be clear
eyes hate - only makes sense in a figuratively way - what you see is what 
you hate(war)
ai same - I and ai=love, "same", in this case "means"? = love means war, I 
am war?(reminds me on a vocaloid song)
A-Z - I say - the first and last letter of the song - AlieZ - I say lie
aibu save - aibu=caress, in this case I would translate it with "I will 
cosy you along, liar"
eid sei - nothing found here until now, you are welcome to help me out

lie heishi war world - heishi=dying, makes sense

It's not funny at all, but I like the speech blending.

Sad thing that the only thing that won't make sense for me is 
"Looser-Krankheit, was ist das?"(loser-illness, what's that?) and I am 
german native speaker. :'D Really, what is that?
comments.author: LaNoir

comments.text:
+pls_respond Sure, but it never talks about a singular "eye." The official 
lyrics from the book say "Eyes-Hate-War." Therefore, it sounds like he 
might have maybe tried to make a pun on the word for love, and failed 
miserably because he used the plural term.
comments.author: NightcoreZombies

comments.author: pls_respond

comments.text:

IF HE'D WRITE HIS LYRICS AND SONG TITLES LIKE A NORMAL PERSON, THIS 
WOULDN'T BE A PROBLEM

Awesome remix. Been waiting for it to come out since the stream.

On another topic, is Aldnoah Zero any good? I've heard it's pretty meh, but 
I need something to watch and I'm considering watching it.﻿
top_comment.author: Conner Austin

comments.text:
+Dliciousization Alright, thanks for the helpful opinion.

I watched Tokyo Ghoul recently and was kind of let down by it, so I was 
kinda hesitant to just pick up a new anime without at least some kind of 
expectation going in.
comments.author: Conner Austin

comments.text:
It depends on your own tastes and how you identify characters.

A lot of people had a lot of trouble understanding Inaho, but I thought he 
was actually a pretty neat character. He's a Gary Stu mixed with the 
stoic/aloof trope, but the way his path of thinking clashes with the other 
main character (Slaine) was really engaging to me. But it's not a bad show 
by any means, the stakes are felt and there are consequences for making 
wrong moves. It's not as Earth shaterringly legendary as it was hyped to 
be, but it's still good.

Next cour airs next season and I'm looking forward to it.
comments.author: Dliciousization

comments.author: LaNoir

comments.text:
+LaNoir Nee, du hast den Satz zu wörtlich übersetzt und somit im Englischen 
einen deutschen Satz gebildet :)
Das Äquivalent deiner gewünschten Aussage wäre wenn überhaupt 'It's sad 
that I can't find'
Aber mit einem Adverb - also entweder 'Sadly' oder 'Unfortuately' ist es 
ein deutlich besserer Stil, weil dein Satz sonst einfach zu Deutsch wirkt.
comments.author: IceclawFirebolt

comments.text:
+IceclawFirebolt
Um das mal ins Deutsche zu übertragen, ich wollte sagen: "Schade, dass ich 
keine Version mit deutschen Untertiteln finden kann." Das andere wäre 
"Leider finde ich keine Version mit deutschen Untertiteln." Kann man nicht 
beides, je nach Ausdruck, im Englischen sagen?
Ich hab mir meinen englischen Wortschatz größtenteils mit anderen Leuten im 
TS erarbeitet, die z.B. als Muttersprache Spanisch sprechen, also kann es 
sein, dass sich von "Noob zu Noob" kleine Fehler eingeschlichen haben, für 
eine Explanation wäre ich also dankbar. ;)
comments.author: LaNoir

comments.text:
+LaNoir  I already guessed my wording may lead to a misunderstanding^^"
Don't worry, your English is fine (you can even skip the 'that' you wanted 
to add, it's not necessary for your sentence :))
What I meant was that you can always improve your English by watching 
something in English (or reading English subs, etc) regardless of your 
language skills :)
I didn't mean to imply your English was bad or anything :D

The only thing I'd change would be 'Sad that I can't find'. I would 
probably use 'Sadly I can't find' instead :)
comments.author: IceclawFirebolt

comments.text:
+LaNoir
*that

captions.text: Even if I take a stand
that I keep hidden in my wardrobe;
only the convenient scars are displayed,
showing me the way to countless victories with effortless strength.
No matter much I polish it, it wears me down,
my thoughts trained to unsteady ideas.
it leaves me looking at nothing but the ground;
In the time I failed to notice,
of that mirror was losing to the past, breaking.
How long do I have to scream to convey my position;
my breath gives out before I can finish,
A-Z Imagination High-of-Do YOU see it?
no matter how many times I open my eyes.
How long do I have to scream to convey my position;
my breath gives out before I can finish,
against a brazen horde of sins.
A signal, do you see it?
Conjecture; what you don't know, Is of your own volition.
A signal, do you see it?
Must be seen with your own eyes.
